title: Wednesday, 21st June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hi!

BE11:03am

It's Wednesday, otherwise known as Day of Rage. Happy Day of Rage!

BE11:03am

It's also Day of the Martyrs in Togo.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

And it's World Humanist Day. And the National Day of Greenland.

BE11:03am

And International Yoga Day. And Go Skateboarding Day. And World Hydrography Day. And International Surfing Day. It's lots of Days.

BE11:03am

Rage is one among your myriad options. Have you considered Hydrography?

11:03 am
BE11:03am

So anyway, picture.

BE11:04am

https://twitter.com/travisk/status/486546731488641024

BE11:04am

Travis should have more time for his ecclesiastical work now, having "resigned" as CEO of Uber.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

It's the kind of resignation where you retain a seat on the board and, with Garrett Camp and Ryan Graves, a majority of the voting rights.

BE11:05am

Story here:

BE11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-80b6-9bfa4c1f83d2

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Kadhim's furious and prescient backgrounder here:

BE11:05am

https://ftalphavil...e-travis-kalanick/

BE11:05am

And an acid dipped cast-forward here:

11:05 am
BE11:05am

https://ftalphavil...-troubled-startup/

BE11:06am

Plus, as a World Hydrography Day special bonus, let's get a picture up of the early front-runner to replace Travis.

BE11:06am

A Mr Sivart C. Kinalack.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

Who'll be a breath of fresh air I'm sure.

undefined
11:06 am
BE11:06am

@GBKrona: PM's back in the country!

BE11:07am

Not back in the office of course, but back in London. At this exact moment I'd guess he's on the Heathrow Express.

BE11:09am

So you've got me again. But there's a not inconceivable possibility that he might be around tomorrow.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

That's tomorrow though. We've today to get through first.

BE11:09am

Starting with Provident Financial.

Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 2,395, down 470 (-16.40%), High: 2,498, Low: 2,303, Volume: 1.43m
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Profit warning. Big one as well.

BE11:10am

Consensus coming down by about 15% this year, 10% next.

BE11:12am

Blamed on operational issues as Home Credit moves towards a new model, rather than any underlying problem.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Both collections and new sales have suffered.

BE11:12am

Which is ahead of the relaunch next month.

BE11:13am

Employee recruitment and training now complete, the statement says, so the message from management is very much "we're through this it's fine."

11:13 am
BE11:13am

However, the statement's kinda weird.

BE11:13am

Blaming "reduced agent effectiveness" .....

BE11:14am

.... which, I think, means fewer agents rather than a reduced ability of the agents to get money out of people.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

......... because that'd raise all sorts of questions about the methods doorstep lenders use to get money out of people, and we really don't want to head into that area of conversation.

BE11:15am

Here's Numis.

BE11:15am

Agent vacancy rates have doubled to 12% this coupled with a poorer performance from the development managers has resulted on fewer customer calls and so, customer collections. The impairment model of Provident means that these will necessarily impact the charge and ability to lend while this problem persists. Sales have declined by £37m in the first five months of the year to the end of May. Provident have guided that HCC is now expected to report a profit of c.£60m for this year, down from the £115m reported last year. The rest of the group is trading in line with internal plans but we would highlight the recent weak economic statistics such as inflation (2.9%), average earnings (2.1%), services PMI (53.8 from 55.8) and most importantly retail sales (0.9% from 4.0%, down excluding food sales). We are however not reducing our forecasts (at this stage) for Vanquis (which is undergoing some heavy investment spend in H1) or Moneybarn which we forecast to deliver strong (underlying 30%) H1 profit growth. Our group EPS forecasts decline 3.3% this year to 164.8p from 170.4p, 2.3% next year to 180.1p from 184.3p and by 2.4% the year after to 187.3p from 192.0p.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

While Provident is a high ROE business (which we like) underlying EPS is expected to fall 6% this year and it commands a PE of 17x. This compares to Aldermore which we forecast will deliver underlying EPS growth of 18% this year and it has a PE of 7x. Our recommendation on Provident moves to Reduce from Hold, our HCC COE (10%) as increased as a consequence of the increased negative earnings risk.

BE11:17am

James Hamilton is the analyst there.

BE11:17am

And RBC's Peter Lenardos is just off the conference call.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Home credit transition: Provident provided some further colour around the disruption to the home credit business, stating that the incentives put in place by management to retain agents were not sufficient, which has resulted in vacancy levels of 12% (or more than double the rate anticipated). While the switch to the new model is scheduled to occur in early July, management expects that it will take a further “two to three months to bed down the new people in the system and the new technology they are using.” In Q3/2017, management focus will be on collections and arrears management primarily so the company expects to see the current £37MM year-on-year decrease in credit issued in the first five months to May 2017 to “expand further in the coming weeks” however we note this has been incorporated in the revised 2017 adjusted PBT guidance. In Q4/2017, management expects the division to have largely returned to “business as usual” and believes there is a “significant sales opportunity” in the quarter, which is seasonally its highest quarter of the year for credit issuances.

BE11:18am

2018 guidance: while the current disruption to collections is not expected to impact 2018 earnings, Provident expects the lost contribution from lower sales in 2017 will have an adverse impact going forward. Management’s best estimate for CCD adjusted PBT in 2018 is ~£100MM, and we currently forecast £135.5MM for the division and £396.0MM for the company. Thus, we estimate a ~35.5MM adverse adjusted PBT impact in 2018 as a result of yesterday’s profit warning, representing a 9% downgrade to our 2018 adjusted diluted EPS estimate, which follows a 15% downgrade to our 2017 adjusted diluted EPS estimate.

BE11:18am

2019 guidance: no indication of the impact to 2019 adjusted PBT was provided however management expects to close the gap to current consensus further in 2019; we believe some downgrades to 2019 consensus earnings are likely.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Dividend: in line with previous commentary, Provident intends to “look-through” the reduced earnings in 2017 to the extent that the earnings shortfall relates to one-off items. Further, management stated it would be willing to go below its dividend cover policy of 1.25x in 2017 – our 2017 dividend forecast currently assumes a dividend cover of 1.25x – thus, despite the reduction in earnings, Provident is unlikely to cut its 2017 dividend, in our opinion.

BE11:19am

Conclusion: management provided some further colour around the disruption to the home credit business as well as the potential impact to earnings going forward; we now estimate a 9% downgrade to our 2018 adjusted diluted EPS estimate, following a 15% downgrade to our 2017 adjusted diluted EPS estimate, and believe that some downgrades to 2019 consensus earnings are also likely. However, we also note that management underestimated the potential impact of the restructuring of the division and the transition to the new operating model – which does not occur until early next month – and there will likely be further disruption next quarter as the new employees and new technology are introduced (which may also be more material than anticipated). As a result, we believe that sufficient uncertainty still exists to warrant the material share price correction today.

BE11:20am

Are there any other listed doorstep lenders left? There was Cattles, which blew up.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

................ International Personal Finance! That's the one I was trying to remember, thanks Fatdaz.

International Personal Finance PLC (IPF:LSE): Last: 157.50, down 5.25 (-3.23%), High: 161.50, Low: 157.50, Volume: 163.38k
BE11:22am

........... though that's mostly about regulatory exposure in central and eastern Europe.

11:22 am
undefined
BE11:23am

Meanwhile, on the riser pile .....

Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,000, up 147 (+3.82%), High: 4,080, Low: 3,983, Volume: 635.05k
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Q1 fine-ish. Premier Inn revpar steady and Costa delivers like-for-like growth, just.

BE11:25am

Guidance stays the same, which isn't unexpected at the first-quarter point, though there might have been some worries that management would edge the range wider.

BE11:26am

Outlook statement is ......... well, can I say banal?

11:26 am
BE11:26am

"we have had a good start to the year [...] which combined with our ongoing cost efficiency programme, gives us confidence that we will make further good progress this year”

BE11:26am

Here's Panmure.

BE11:27am

We assume management remains happy with consensus/PG expectations for £589m PBT. We model 1% RevPAR growth for Premier Inn and 4,200 room additions (target reiterated). At Costa we model 1% LFL growth and margins down by 100bp, broadly in line with guidance, with targets reiterated for 230-250 new Costa additions and c.1,250 Costa Express installations.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The shares have slipped back below the level they retreated to on the day of FY17 results (25 April), reflecting investor caution towards the UK consumer in the context of soggy macro (real wage deflation) and industry (footfall) data points. On our FY18 forecasts Whitbread trades on 15.3x PE and 9.8x EV/EBITDA; the low end of the range over the past five years (average c.11x), which is understandable given LFL sales and profit growth at Costa is running at five year lows. Our SOTP analysis suggests investors are getting Costa for 8.1x EBITDA, assuming an 11x multiple for PI (20% discount to asset-light, international peers) and an 8x multiple for Restaurants (in-line with pub/restaurant peers). This feels inherently cheap (vs. Starbucks on 14x), albeit we retain some caution over having to pay up for Costa international growth potential without evidence for the level of sustainable cash generation of this business. Reiterate HOLD.

BE11:28am

And JPM off the conference call.

BE11:28am

Comments on Premier Inn RevPAR vs the market. In Q1, the headline RevPAR performance was -1pt below the UK midscale and economy market, better than the -2pt optical underperformance in FY17. Against expectations we believe this was primarily driven by better Occupancy (broadly flat at 71.2%), showing no material dilution from ongoing openings. Management suggested that Occupancy performance in such a low occupancy quarter as Q1 was not necessarily a good read for the rest of the year, but overall “started the year positively” and “remain confident”. Generally CFO Nicholas Cadbury reiterated that despite the strength in the quarter, management’s working assumptions remains UK RevPAR tracking GDP growth.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

You'll remember the discussion in recent weeks about whether Premier Inn had boxed itself in by trying to stay discount (which apparently means staying sub £200 a room in prime London) while others are moving into the territory slightly above.

BE11:30am

Today's results don't move that thesis on one iota.

BE11:30am

CEO Alison Brittain reiterated that Premier Inn “will restrict
their inventory on OTAs in a bid to remain strong on the direct online channels”, and acknowledged that Premier Inn could have released more inventory on OTAs to capture a larger share of the strong UK inbound tourism volumes: “we are not using the flow of tourists to drive occupancy”

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Comments on Costa pricing. Management commented that price increases continue to bring a c. 1% net like-for-like benefit, suggesting most of the performance in the quarter was price-led. CEO Alison Brittain acknowledged further pricing headroom for Costa when compared to speciality coffee brands, but noted further pressure from lower-priced coffee alternatives including a recent campaign from McCafe.

BE11:31am

Is a McCafe what I think it is?

BE11:31am

Anyway .....

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Valuation
Our DCF-derived Apr-18 price target is 4,000p. We use a WACC of 8.3%, 4.5% medium-term growth funded by capex 2.0x above D&A, 2.0% terminal growth, and assume flat EBITDA margins at 26.2% after 2022.

undefined
BE11:33am

Turning our back on he big stuff for a moment, there's this.

11:33 am
Hornby PLC (HRN:LSE): Last: 33.00, up 1.75 (+5.60%), High: 35.25, Low: 32.25, Volume: 35.54m
BE11:34am

A bid! Sort of! But not really!

BE11:35am

This is Phoenix going over 50% and having to make a mandatory offer.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

http://www.investe...1706210842446916I/

BE11:36am

As in Phoenix Asset Management.

BE11:36am

Brace yourself.

11:02 am
BE11:03am

Hello, welcome along, this is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily junk with the stuff and whatnot.

BE11:37am

There's a useful backgrounder on the activist fight going on that prompted this nonsense.

BE11:38am

From Kate Burgess, back in April: https://www.ft.com...-a454-ab04428977f9

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And as noted on the right, it follows very closely on from the Stanley Gibbons bid that wasn't.

BE11:39am

It's been a busy month for hobbyists.

BE11:39am

Anyway, this all rather overshadows Hornby's numbers earlier in the day.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Which were dire, as @FJP says, but also in line with an April warning.

BE11:41am

Hornby is now a turnaround story under new CEO Steve Cooke, of course. Add your own joke about turning around trains here, if you must.

BE11:41am

I'll quote Numis.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

FY pre-tax loss of £6.3m was as forecast (NSe £6.3m), with the trends in revenue (-15% to £47m), operating costs (-11% to £24m), and gross margin (H2 +240bp) all reflecting successful execution of the Turnaround initiatives: 1) Product ranges have been rationalised (SKUs -40%) and sales channels refined (focus on independents, largely exited concessions) to focus on profitable activities, 2) The cost base has been rationalised, particularly in Europe, 3) Stock (-29%) has been managed down to an appropriate level, and 4) Cash flow performance has improved, with H2 seeing a positive operating cash flow performance. Boosted by the fund-raise last year, Hornby ended the period with net cash of £1.5m.

BE11:41am

Having completed the first phase of its Turnaround plan, these results see management outline its focus for the next stage. This includes building market share and margin in core hobby brands, particularly in the independent channel, improving execution in Scalextric, building EU and US sales from the new base, and delivering ongoing efficiencies in the cost base.

BE11:41am

Current trading is complicated by a number of factors, including the UK stock clearance in the comparative period last year, and EU product release timing. However, the statement notes that, excluding the PY stock clearance, UK/US sales for the 11wks to 18-June are only ‘slightly down’. Moreover, gross margin is 5 percentage points higher. Overall, trading is described as ‘in line with expectations’.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

We continue to expect Hornby to achieve a small profit in FY18 and believe management’s focus on prioritising profitability and a right-sized cost base is the right approach. With the key elements of the Turnaround Plan – cost streamlining, range rationalisation, re-engagement with independent customers – now in place, and Hornby moving into Phase 2 of its Turnaround, we retain our positive stance.

BE11:44am

What Hornby wants to do is connect three trains together and call it a .... I dunno, a Fiddle spinner.

BE11:44am

(Model railway joke. Niche. https://en.wikiped...g/wiki/Fiddle_yard )

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:44am

Back up then.

BE11:45am

Who was talking Capita? Someone was.

11:45 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 681.00, up 10 (+1.49%), High: 692.00, Low: 679.00, Volume: 1.01m
BE11:45am

Today's upgrade comes from HSBC.

BE11:46am

(@alewis2005: accepted.)

11:46 am
BE11:46am

And they've done it with an open letter to the new CEO, who doesn't yet exist.

BE11:46am

To whom it may concern,

BE11:46am

... it begins.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Under the stewardship of Rod Aldridge, Paddy Doyle, and Paul Pindar, Capita grew and changed rapidly. It became complex. As new CEO of Capita this complexity will be your foe. Capita uses a multitude of revenue recognition methods; it changes the constituent businesses of each division, almost, quarterly. It buys and sells businesses to open itself to new sources of opportunity. Most importantly it signs long duration, complex, business process outsourcing (BPO) contracts. Doing so without incurring unforeseen risks is hard. Your public sector clients want to save money, they also seem to care more, now, about how much money you make. Embedding IT purchasing in contracts, enlarging the scope of contracts during their duration and staffing contracts with temps are all getting harder. Such offsetting of risks is getting tougher, making suitable returns harder. If the current direction of political swing is maintained these issues may get tougher. To steer your business, you will need to understand the needs of politicians, civil servants and exactly how each contract, and employee, makes money. You may choose to look closely at accruals. You will have to master some quite labyrinthine cross charging between business lines.

BE11:47am

You may have time. In the shorter term, an accounting change, asset write-downs, and cost saving programmes may well bring a pause in earnings estimates downgrades. The divestment programme will alleviate the pressure on the balance sheet. Capita is a good business, it creates process solutions for the public and the private sector, and there will be demand. Focus on de-cluttering, simplifying, and understanding the risks inherent in long contracts, and complex accounting. Understand remuneration structures of bid teams, what are you paying them to do? You can sustainably improve the business and the market’s perception of it.

BE11:48am

A big prize. If you outline a solid plan the market will reward you, if you deliver upon it, with solid simple execution, this will be sustained. We increase our target price to 820p (from 590p) using 12-month forward EV/EBITA of 13.5x (recovery multiple, towards the upper end of 9.3x-15.0x, current 9.4x on consensus) and EV/CE of 1.9x (lower CE and higher RoCE, 1.5x previously). This implies upside of 22%. Hence we upgrade the stock to Buy (from Hold previously), which we think reflects our more conservative estimates, the political risk, and the level of execution skill that will be required.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Yours Sincerely ...

Disclosures & Disclaimer
This report must be read with the disclosures and the analyst certifications in the Disclosure appendix, and with the Disclaimer, which forms part of it.

BE11:49am

It's actually written by Matthew Lloyd and team. But for some reason he's not added his signature, so it does look like it's been signed by Disclosures & Disclaimer.

undefined
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Queen's up.

BE11:51am

Utilities down.

BE11:51am

Mention in the text from Liz about tackling "unfair" energy markets.

11:51 am
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 207.70, up 5.6 (+2.77%), High: 209.70, Low: 204.50, Volume: 14.26m
United Utilities Group PLC (UU.:LSE): Last: 941.50, up 3 (+0.32%), High: 946.14, Low: 935.26, Volume: 1.05m
SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,484, up 9 (+0.61%), High: 1,504, Low: 1,478, Volume: 1.62m
11:51 am
National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 1,010, down 8.5 (-0.83%), High: 1,022, Low: 1,008, Volume: 2.04m
BE11:53am

Specifics are non existent, of course, because that's how these things work. But you'll remember the Sun reporting last week that the tariff cap proposal could be scrapped for being too un-Tory.

BE11:54am

And replaced with more smart meters. What we have looks slightly different.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Anyway, as noted, Centrica's flogged some lossmaking power stations which is why it's running on a bit.

BE11:55am

UBS has figures.

BE11:55am

We estimate the sale price is close to the BV of £310m (UBSe) after write-downs in 2014/15 and reflects the expected value of capacity contracts the two plants have from 2017/18 through 2020/21. In 2016, ex capacity payments, Centrica's thermal fleet reported losses of £51m of which we believe about half would be linked to Langage & Humber – despite improvements in spark spreads from £6 to £10/MWh and increasing load factors. Following the sale of Centrica's E&P assets earlier this month we assume this transaction largely brings to an end Centrica's divestment programme.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Closure of Rough and Queen's Speech could also be positive
Rough Storage (CSL) also reported operating losses in 2016 of £52m and technical tests suggest the asset is not now economic to maintain. Closure could bring welcome relief, and might lead to a change in the regulatory framework – if the government believes the Rough Storage asset is a part of critical national infrastructure.

BE11:56am

Valuation: Neutral at (SOTP) PT 215p until plans for the tariff cap are confirmed To be conservative our numbers factor in a 1/3 reduction in Standard Tariff margins from 2018E, equivalent to a c£200m annual EBIT impact, and PT of 215p reflects both a lower EPS and a higher required DY to recognise the higher risk on the shares. We also factor in the latest FX/commodity and unavailability of Rough storage. But we also note that a range of outcomes remains possible: in our upside case, if policy changes are benign the shares could recover to 245p. In our downside case, if margins were reduced by 2/3 (from c6% to c2%) we believe the shares could fall to 185p.

BE11:57am

Okay, so what exactly has Liz said? The government will bring forward "measures to help tackle unfair practices in the energy market to help reduce energy bills".

11:58 am
BE11:58am

There was a BBC report saying the tariff cap bill would become a consultation. Does this mean a consultation?

BE11:58am

This really is no way to run a democracy.

undefined
11:58 am
BE11:59am

And ...................... DPL. If we must.

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,287, up 60 (+1.86%), High: 3,333, Low: 3,272, Volume: 492.94k
BE11:59am

It's a housebuilder, so obviously it's beaten forecasts and raised 2018 guidance.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

That's what housebuilders do. Even ones that are over-exposed to a London market that's as clearly and transparently dysfunctional as Mocking Spongebob.

BE12:01pm

Here comes Morgan Stanley.

BE12:01pm

FYApr17 results well ahead. Revenues were £2.72bn (Cons: £2.58bn, MS £2.58bn), while EBIT was £756m (Cons: £705m, MS £741m, representing an operating margin of 27.8% (Cons: 27.1%, MS: 28.6%). Basic EPS were 467.8p (Cons: 418p, MS: 432p). The group's dividend per share was 185p, down 2.6%. Net cash was £286m (MSe: £147m).

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Guidance – unchanged on earnings... The group said it was on track to deliver "at least" £3.0 billion of pre-tax profit in the five years beginning 1 May 2016, with £812.4 million delivered in the first year. At the low end this implies a minimum average PBT of £550m in the forthcoming years.

BE12:02pm

... unchanged on dividend payout. The group has committed to a shareholder return of £8.0 per share cumulatively for the next 4 years, or £2.0 per share per annum, in line with previous guidance.

BE12:02pm

Outlook/market commentary. "The housing market has stabilised in London and the South East but, while Berkeley is in excellent shape with further additions to our unrivalled land bank in the period, it is an inescapable fact that we are facing a number of headwinds and a period of prolonged uncertainty. Brexit and wider global macro instability impact both confidence and sentiment and will result in constrained investment levels. At the same time, the headwinds from changes in recent years to SDLT and mortgage interest deductibility, coupled with the planning environment's increasing demands from the combination of Affordable Housing, CIL, Section 106 obligations and review mechanisms, are resulting in reduced levels of new housing starts in London".

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Thesis recap. Berkeley is our least preferred name of the four UK housebuilders we cover, given its falling earnings trajectory and its focus on London, where we expect capital values to underperform in the short/medium term. A boom in London house prices and volumes has benefited the company in recent years, which we think is in the process of (at least partial) unwinding. We think falling earnings will drive share price drift, absent a big departure from the group's medium-term guidance, with the group's low P/E (7x Dec 2017e EPS) and strong 6% dividend yield and/or buybacks providing some support.

BE12:04pm

You'll note the line about affordable housing obligations, The Community Infrastructure Levy and Section 106 limits to reduce their impact on the community.

BE12:05pm

And how the effect has been to reduce the number of housing starts in London.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

I'd rather hoped that requirements to act more responsibly would lead housebuilders to act more responsibly. Instead, they're building fewer houses. That's ............ bad?

BE12:06pm

Have Peel Hunt as well.

BE12:06pm

Full-year results were stronger than expected with PBT up 53%.
While the five-year guidance of at least £3bn PBT was
unchanged, management has indicated FY18 will deliver
earnings at least as high as FY17 – implying a 7-8% upgrade to
consensus. Concerns about the macro and political environment
remain (especially in London), but we continue to believe the
impressive land bank contains plenty of unrecognised value in a
market that remains severely undersupplied. Remains a Buy.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Building fewer houses "in a market that remains severely undersupplied" is .......................... bad? I dunno any more.

BE12:08pm

And here's Canaccord.

BE12:09pm

The group has delivered a very strong set of results slightly above expectations. PBT of £812m was modestly higher than our expectation of £792m. The results are testament to the group's strong management of the cycle with NAV growth of c.+15% and operating margins of close to 28%. Clearly, these strong results reflect the strong forward order book built up during the very strong London market a few years ago and well bought land post the financial crisis. Balance sheet remains strong in terms of quality of land bank and net cash was also better than we expected at £285m. Focus will likely be on current trading and outlook comments. Management has reiterated its view that the London and South-east market has stabilised but is understandably cautious given the current macro and political risks. Despite these wider market risks, the group looks well set to deliver its £3bn profit guidance over the next five years and expects profits to be higher in the current financial year compared to those reported this morning for FY2017. Consensus looks well supported and could possibly edge up very modestly on profit guidance comments. Clearly, macro risks are elevated currently, but Berkeley looks in great shape and is likely to navigate these risks better than most. All very solid with the group is good shape to deal with the current uncertainties. Valuation is now back to a slight premium to the sector, which is deserved in our view.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

(@Fatdaz: haven't seen that.)

BE12:10pm

And finally, have Jefferies on the transaction data.

BE12:10pm

May’s housing transactions fell 3% vs April, but increased 13% vs May 16, as we continue to lap easier comps. Transactions are down 7% YTD but we expect this decline to ease as we move through the year and away from the distorting of the changes to stamp duty. Transactions over the past three months are 4% below the levels seen before the changes to stamp duty were announced.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Cracking chart attached to that.

BE12:12pm

BE12:13pm

Remarkably constant, that, in what should be a seasonal market. It's almost as if supply is deliberately constrained to undershoot demand.

12:13 pm
BE12:14pm

And that those doing the constraining, the housebuilders, have the advantage of a dirty great state subsidy that allows them to perpetuate the cartel.

BE12:14pm

Anyway.

undefined
12:14 pm
BE12:14pm

Wow, look at the time. Thanks for all the comments folks.

BE12:15pm

Back tomorrow, either in singular or plural.

BE12:15pm

Until then, afternoon all.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

On 7 April 2017, a requisition for a general meeting was received by Hornby from representatives of NPIL. The requisition stated that the purpose was to propose changes to the board of Hornby and, consequently, make changes to the business strategy of Hornby.

On 25 April 2017, PAMP (for itself and on behalf of the other members of the Phoenix Concert Party) entered into an irrevocable agreement, together with Ruffer LLP and Downing LLP in respect of 53.96 per cent. of the outstanding voting share capital of Hornby, to vote against the resolution proposed by NPIL in the requisition.

On 8 May 2017, Hornby received a letter from the representatives of NPIL withdrawing NPIL's request to proceed with convening the requisitioned general meeting of Hornby. On 16 May 2017 the requisitioned general meeting of Hornby was adjourned indefinitely.

After engaging with representatives of NPIL, Phoenix UK Fund has agreed to enter into the Acquisition to acquire all of the Hornby shares owned by NPIL.

Prior to the Acquisition, the Phoenix Concert Party were interested in Hornby Shares which, in aggregate, carried not less than 30 per cent. of the voting rights of Hornby, but not more than 50 per cent. of such voting rights. As a result of the Acquisition, the percentage of Hornby Shares carrying voting rights in which the Phoenix Concert Party is interested has increased to more than 50 per cent. of the voting rights of Hornby.

Rule 9 of the Takeover Code requires that where a shareholder, together with persons acting in concert with him, has an interest of not less than 30 per cent., but does not hold more than 50 per cent., of a company's voting share capital, and then acquires an interest in any further shares he is required to make a mandatory cash offer for the entire issued share capital not already owned by him and persons acting in concert with him. As a result of the Acquisition, and pursuant to Rule 9 of the Takeover Code, Phoenix UK Fund, on behalf of the Phoenix Concert Party, is therefore required to make an offer for all the Hornby Shares not already owned by it or by persons acting in concert with it.
